context: The Estonian word 'naeratus' means smile in English. It refers to the facial expression of happiness or amusement, typically involving turning up the corners of the mouth and crinkling around the eyes. The dictionary shows various types of smiles including 'lapse naeratus' (child's smile), 'pilke naeratus' (smirk), 'võitja naeratus' (winner's smile), and 'õnne naeratus' (smile of happiness). The word can be used in different forms: nominative singular 'naeratus', plural 'naeratused', and genitive form 'naeratuse'. It comes from the verb root 'naeratama' (to smile) and related to 'naerma' (to laugh).
